title: Kinetic study of adsorption and photo-decolorization of Reactive Red 198 on TiO2 surface
abstract: Recycling and reuse of wastewater after purification will reduce the environmental pollution as well as fulfill the increasing demand of water. Adsorption-based water treatment process is very popular for dye-house wastewater treatment. The present study deals with treatment of wastewater contaminated by reactive dye. TiO2 is used as adsorbent and the spent adsorbent has been regenerated by Advanced Oxidation Process (AOP), without using any other chemicals. TiO2 adsorbs dye molecules and then those dye molecules have been oxidized via a photocatalytic reaction in presence of UV irradiation. Kinetics of dye adsorption and photocatalytic oxidation reaction has been developed in this study. Photocatalyst adsorbent (TiO2) has been reused several times after regeneration. The activity of catalyst decreases after each cycle; due to poisoning cause by intermediate by-products. Kinetic of this catalyst deactivation has been incorporated with L–H model to develop the photocatalytic reaction kinetic model

Title: Kinetic study of adsorption and photo-decolorization of
Reactive Red 198 on TiO2 surface

Datta, S. Bandyopadhyay

Kinetic study of adsorption and photo-decolorization of Reactive Red 198 on TiO2 1 
surface 2 
S. Dutta1*, S. A.Parsons2, C. Bhattacharjee1, P. Jarvis2, S. Datta1, S. Bandyopadhyay3 3 
1 Chemical Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata – 700032, India 4 
2 Centre for Water Science, Cranfield University, Cranfield, Bebfordshire MK43 0AL, UK  5 
3 Central Glass and Ceramic Research Institute, Kolkata – 700032, India  6 
 7 
Abstract 8 
Recycling and reuse of wastewater after purification will reduce the 9 
environmental pollution as well as fulfill the increasing demand of water.  Adsorption-10 
based water treatment process is very popular for dye-house wastewater treatment. The 11 
present study deals with treatment of wastewater contaminated by reactive dye. TiO2 is 12 
used as adsorbent and the spent adsorbent has been regenerated by Advanced Oxidation 13 
Process (AOP), without using any other chemicals. TiO2 adsorbs dye molecules and then 14 
those dye molecules have been oxidized via a photocatalytic reaction in presence of UV 15 
irradiation. Kinetics of dye adsorption and photocatalytic oxidation reaction has been 16 
developed in this study. Photocatalyst adsorbent (TiO2) has been reused several times 17 
after regeneration. The activity of catalyst decreases after each cycle; due to poisoning 18 
cause by intermediate by-products. Kinetic of this catalyst deactivation has been 19 
incorporated with L-H model to develop the photocatalytic reaction kinetic model.  20 
 21 
Keywords: Adsorption, Advanced Oxidation Process, Catalyst regeneration, Reactive 22 
Red 198, TiO2-Photocatalysis, Catalyst activity 23 
* Revised Manuscript

E-mail: ss.dutta@hotmail.com (Suman Dutta) 2 
1. Introduction 3 
Demand of water is increasing day by day, accordingly recycling and reuse of 4 
water from various sources are being given due priority in recent times. Wastewater from 5 
industries, domestic wastewater, and municipal wastewater can be recycled after proper 6 
purification. Recycling of textile effluent is very essential because, dyeing 1 kg of cotton 7 
with reactive dyes requires an average of 70 – 150 litre water [1]. Various research works 8 
have been carried out on dye-house wastewater purification by Advanced Oxidation 9 
Process employing TiO2 catalyst under UV irradiation. The advantages of UV/TiO2 10 
process are manifold; it produces less residual pollutants compared to other conventional 11 
processes and reduces the disposal cost, consequently water treatment cost [2]. Some 12 
authors investigated decolorization of textile effluent using ozone, which was found to be 13 
highly effective [3] AOP (UV/TiO2) produces hydroxyl radical, which is able to oxidize a 14 
range of organic compounds significantly faster than ozone [4].  15 
Decolorization of wastewater contaminated with RR198 was studied by Robert et. 16 
al [5] in which TiO2 powder was used in colloidal form.  Result of this investigation 17 
showed that use of TiO2 powder in colloidal form was much more effective than the 18 
immobilized system because of higher available surface area. Various authors have 19 
investigated adsorption of reactive dyes on different adsorbent like activated carbon [6], 20 
fly ash [7], and chitosan/oil palm ash composite beads [8] etc. Different synthesized and 21 
commercial acyclic ester resins were also used for dye adsorption efficiently [9]. All 22 
these studies confirm that the dye removal is possible by adsorption. 23 
Page 3 of 27
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
3 
Beside these, other processes like electrochemical process [10], 1 
coagulation/flocculation process [11], and microbial decolorization [12] were studied by 2 
researchers. But the disposal of these spent adsorbents and final waste cause additional 3 
environmental pollution. Hence, regeneration of spent adsorbent is the way to solve this 4 
disposal problem. Activated carbon adsorbent can be regenerated using some chemicals 5 
(NaOH and HCl) [13].  6 
With reference to the previous investigations, we have emphasized the 7 
regeneration of TiO2 catalyst without using any chemicals. Only UV irradiation has been 8 
employed to decompose adsorbed dye molecules by photocatalytic oxidation reaction. 9 
We also studied the possibility of recycling and reuse of TiO2 catalyst after regeneration. 10 
TiO2 catalyst has been reused in five successive cycles and the result shows that TiO2 11 
catalyst can be recycled after regeneration. A kinetic model equation of photocatalytic 12 
reaction has been developed considering deactivation of catalyst due to effect of 13 
intermediate product and some inorganic ions [14] on the catalyst surface. Kinetic of 14 
catalyst deactivation also has been studied in this present work.  15 
 16 
2. Materials and methods  17 
Chemicals used for this study are, Reactive Red 198 (MW: 923 g.mol-1), which is 18 
a diazo dye (Fig.1). This dye was supplied from a dye-house near Kolkata, West Bengal, 19 
India. TiO2 powder Hombikat UV – 100 was used as catalyst. This catalyst was supplied 20 
by Sachtleben Chemie GmbH. The catalyst contains 99 % of anatase with a specific 21 
surface area (BET) >250 m2.g-1 and primary crystal size < 10 nm dia. Water used for all 22 
these experiments is deionized water.   23 
Page 4 of 27

4 
2.1 Experimental setup 1 
A Jar Tester manufactured by Phipps and Bird, Virginia, USA was used for 2 
experimental purpose. The Jar Tester comprising six jars with six stirrers (uniform 3 
speed). The volume of each jar is 1 litre. A UV illuminating bulb was placed on the top of 4 
these jars. Stirrers of this Jar Tester consist of 2 flat bladed rectangular paddles with an 5 
area 1.9 × 10 -3 m2. A uniform speed of 150 rpm has been maintained by using a control 6 
panel with digital display. The schematic diagram of the jar tester has been shown in Fig. 7 
2.   8 
 9 
2.2 Experimental procedure  10 
Firstly adsorption of dye was studied to ensure the decolorization by 11 
photocatalytic reaction on TiO2 surface, because the substances that are adsorbed strongly 12 
degrade faster [15]. A series of experiment were conducted to find the optimum pH and 13 
TiO2 dose for adsorption. Dark adsorption test of dye on TiO2 surface was carried out in 14 
the Jar Tester. All of these experiments were conducted in presence of infrared light to 15 
prevent any decolorization of dyes by photocatalytic reaction. This test was performed 16 
with six different TiO2 doses in between 1 g.L-1 and 5 g.L-1. This test was conducted at 17 
three different pH (pH: 3, 5.5, and 7) with an initial dye concentration 350 mg.L-1. The 18 
pH of the test solution (mixture of dye solution and TiO2 adsorbent) was controlled using 19 
10 M HCl and 10 M NaOH solution. After starting the experimental run, samples were 20 
collected from the Jar Tester with time to time. Then the collected samples were filtered 21 
using 0.45 µm polyethersulfone microfiltration membranes (Pall, Gelman Laboratory, 22 
Michigan) to separate the TiO2 particles. After filtration, the concentration of dye was 23 
Page 5 of 27
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
5 
measured using a spectrophotometer (Jenway 6505 UV/Vis spectrophotometer; 1 
Dunmow, Essex, UK) at a wavelength λmax =516 nm.  2 
After completing adsorption test, decolorization test of dyes was carried out in 3 
presence of UV ray illumination. A UV light illuminating bulb (100 watt) was used for 4 
this purpose. Samples were collected and filtered as earlier and concentrations of dyes 5 
were measured using an UV- Vis spectrophotometer. The dye decolorization test was 6 
also conducted without TiO2 and only in presence of UV irradiation to verify if it is 7 
catalytic reaction. Viability of TiO2 recycling was tested after both adsorption and 8 
decolorization test. A five cycles experiment was performed with TiO2 catalyst and 9 
RR198; the initial concentration of dye and catalyst was 350 m g.L-1 and 5 g.L-1 10 
respectively. TiO2 was filtered by 0.45 µm microfiltration membrane after each cycle and 11 
reused to the next cycle.    12 
 13 
3. Kinetics of photo-decolorization of RR198 on TiO2 surface 14 
In presence of UV illumination and TiO2 in aqueous solution, the azo bond (-15 
N=N-) of RR198 breaks down and produces some colorless intermediate product. Those 16 
colorless intermediates goes further oxidation to produce non-toxic final product.  17 
We consider the following reactions take place during photo-decolorization of reactive 18 
dye. In presence of UV irradiation TiO2 in aqueous solution produces electrons (e-) and 19 
holes (h+) as:      20 
TiO2 + hν 
1k   e- + h+                                                            (1) 21 
Where h is Plank’s constant and ν is frequency of UV irradiation.  22 
Again some electrons and holes combine and produce heat 23

and Eq. (2) depends only on the concentration of catalyst.  3

surface adsorb water molecules and negatively charged hydroxyl ions  5 
H2O +  H+ + OH- + STiO2

based on the above mentioned reactions.   18

4. Results and Discussions 18 
4.1 Dark Adsorption of RR198 on TiO2 surface 19 
Results of this study show that adsorption capacity of RR198 on TiO2 catalyst 20 
surface is very high at acidic condition. The point of zero charge of TiO2 (pHpzc) is close 21 
Page 9 of 27
Ac
ce
pte
d M
an
us
cri
pt
 
 
9 
to pH 6.8. At pH higher than 6.8 TiO2 surface becomes negatively charged according to 1 
the electrochemical equilibrium: 2 
TiOH + OH-   H2O + TiO
-                                                           (24) 3 
And at pH lower than 6.8 TiO2 surface becomes positively charged  4 
TiOH + H+    Ti – OH2
+                                                      (25) 5 
RR198 (Fig.1) contains negatively charged sulfonate groups thus at acidic condition 6 
interaction between positively charged catalyst surface and negatively charged dyes favor 7 
the adsorption.  At any pH (pH 7) higher than pHpzc, the adsorption capacity is relatively 8 
low whereas adsorption capacity is high at pH (pH 3 and 5.5) lower than pHpzc; as shown 9 
in Fig. 3.  10 
 Fig. 4 shows adsorption quantity vs time plot. This figure shows that most of 11 
adsorption takes place within 20 minutes from the starting and equilibrium reaches after 1 12 
hr.  13 
Fig. 5 represents the Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherms; values of 14 
constants are given in Table 1. It is clear from Table 1 that Langmuir isotherm fits 15 
experimental data better than the Freundlich isotherm. The value of dimensionless 16 
separation factor ( LR ) indicates that the Langmuir isotherm is of favorable type.    17

4.2 Photo-decolorization of RR198 on TiO2 catalyst 7 
Eq. (20) shows that rate of photo-decolorization depends on the adsorbed quantity 8 
of dye on catalyst surface ([ ]adsDye ). Eq. (21) has been developed considering Langmuir 9 
adsorption isotherm. Experimental data of photo-decolorization reaction have been fitted 10 
to the Eq. (23) as shown in Fig. 6. Initially the activity of catalyst is 1, as we use fresh 11 
catalyst.  Fitting the experimental data for pH 3 (R2 = 0.991) the Eq. (23) becomes 12

4.3 Recycling of TiO2 catalyst 18 
Fig. 7 describes the dye concentration ratio vs. time (hr) plot during catalyst 19 
recycling experiment. The subsequent cycles are taking longer time than the preceding 20 
one, because the activity of catalyst decreases due to poising. RR198 contains sulfonate 21

ce

11 
group so there must be inorganic sulfate ion in final solution; this sulfate ions even at low 1 
concentration reduce the oxidation rate [14]. 2 
  3 
4.4 Calculation of catalyst activity for successive cycles 4 
Experimental results show that recycling of catalyst is possible after regeneration. 5 
Incomplete oxidation of dye causes catalyst poisoning due to presence of intermediate 6 
product. The calculated value of initial rate of reaction ( 0ir ) and catalyst activity ( a ) for 7 
each cycle have given in Table 2.  8 
We consider 1st order decay of catalyst activity, and we have the equation 9

against starting time of each cycle (R2 = 0.975) from Table 2 we get 12 
0.10341.02 ta e                        (32) 13

deactivation co-efficient ( cdk ) is 0.1034 hr

5. Conclusion  1 
The present study shows that TiO2 adsorbs RR198 effectively at acidic condition 2 
(pH 3) and adsorption follows Langmuir isotherm (R2 = 0.99) better than Freundlich 3 
isotherm (R2 = 0.96). Regeneration of spent adsorbent is possible by oxidizing the dye 4 
molecules via a photo-decolorization reaction using UV illumination. Photo-5 
decolorization reaction follows the L-H kinetics (R2 = 0.99). This study shows that 6 
recycling of catalyst is also possible after regeneration. The activity of catalyst decreases 7 
due to poising and deactivation which follows first order kinetics.    8 
 9

under British Council Higher Education Link Programme. The authors would like to 13
